The Act is titled the "Cliff Alleviation at Last Minute Act" or the "CALM Act." It includes provisions for permanent extension and gradual increase in certain tax rates on income, capital gains, and dividends. The "CALM Act" includes provisions for permanent extension and gradual increase in certain tax rates on income, capital gains, and dividends. Section 901 of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 is not applicable to specific provisions and amendments. Subsection (i) of section 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust income tax rates for taxable years 2013 and 2014. The text chunk refers to amending income tax rates for taxable years 2013 and 2014 by inserting specific percentages and adjusting the table accordingly. The text chunk amends income tax rates for taxable years 2013 and 2014 by inserting specific percentages and adjusting the table accordingly. It also includes a permanent extension of estate tax law. The text chunk excludes certain provisions from the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 and the Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization, and Job Creation Act of 2010. It also amends the exclusion equivalent of unified credit to $3,500,000 in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The text chunk amends the estate tax rates and exclusion equivalent in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It increases the exclusion equivalent to $3,500,000 and adjusts the maximum estate tax rate to 45 percent. The estate tax rates are amended in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The exclusion equivalent is increased to $3,500,000, and the maximum estate tax rate is adjusted to 45 percent. The tax rates for different estate values are specified, with percentages increasing as the estate value rises. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to reflect a decrease in the applicable credit amount for gift tax. Sections 2011, 2057, and 2604 are repealed to remove unnecessary provisions. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to decrease the applicable credit amount for gift tax by repealing sections 2011, 2057, and 2604. The amendments made by this section will apply to estates of decedents dying, generation-skipping transfers, and gifts made after December 31, 2012. TITLE II--DISCRETIONARY SPENDING CUTS

SEC. 201. DISCRETIONARY SPENDING CUTS. Section 251A of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include considerations for reductions achieved under the authority of the Social Security Act. OMB is authorized to determine fund reductions for fiscal years 2013 through 2021 to meet deficit reduction targets. For fiscal years 2013 through 2021, OMB will allocate funds to discretionary appropriations and direct spending accounts in defense and nondefense functions. OMB will submit a report to Congress detailing fund reductions, and the President will order a sequestration. In 2021, the President will order a sequestration to reduce accounts as determined, and there are procedures for Congressional disapproval through a joint resolution introduced after receiving the Office of Management and Budget report. In 2021, the President will order a sequestration to reduce accounts as determined. Congressional disapproval can prevent sequestration if a joint resolution is enacted within 60 days of receiving the Office of Management and Budget report. The Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 allows the President to order a sequestration for the fiscal year. Joint resolutions introduced in the House or Senate must be referred to the respective Budget Committees and cannot be reported before the 8th day after introduction. If a committee does not report a joint resolution within 15 days of its introduction, the committee is discharged from further consideration. The joint resolution is then placed on the House calendar. Once a joint resolution is reported or deemed discharged by the committee, any Member can move to proceed with it. The motion to proceed with the joint resolution is highly privileged in the House of Representatives and privileged in the Senate. It is not debatable, subject to amendment, or postponement. A motion to reconsider the vote on the motion is not allowed. If agreed to, the resolution remains unfinished business until disposed of. Debate on the joint resolution is limited to 10 hours, divided equally between those in favor and those opposing. Further debate limitations are in order and not debatable. Amendments, postponements, or reconsiderations of the vote are not allowed. The final vote on passage follows immediately. The final vote on passage of a joint resolution follows immediately after a 10-hour debate, with limited debate time for each side and no allowance for amendments, postponements, or reconsiderations. Appeals on procedural rulings are decided without debate, and coordination with the other house is required before passage. The final vote on passage of a joint resolution follows a 10-hour debate with limited debate time for each side and no amendments, postponements, or reconsiderations allowed. Appeals on procedural rulings are decided without debate, and coordination with the other house is required before passage. If one House passes a joint resolution and receives one from the other House, specific procedures apply, including not referring the other House's resolution to a committee and voting on the other House's resolution for final passage. The rulemaking power of the Senate and House of Representatives allows for the establishment of rules for joint resolutions, which are deemed part of each House's rules but only apply to that House's procedures for joint resolutions. The constitutional right of each House to change its rules regarding procedures is also recognized. Title III of the Social Security Act is amended to implement entitlement reforms that aim to reduce expenditures by $40 billion annually from 2014 to 2023, with beneficiary protections in place. The Senate acknowledges the need for comprehensive tax reform in the 113th Congress.
